data.title: Mac OS X hotkeys don't work right for the Dvorak - QWERTY ⌘ layout
data.body:
This is on Mac OS X 10.11.4.  I use a keyboard layout called "Dvorak - QWERTY ⌘".  What that does is let me type in Dvorak most of the time, but whenever I press the ⌘ (command) key, Mac switches back to QWERTY for as long as I hold the key down.  That lets me use hotkeys like a normal QWERTY user, e.g. ⌘-Z to undo is the same keypress as QWERTY and makes a lot of apps easier to use.

Unfortunately Godot must be detecting keys at a lower level and doesn't respect the switch back to QWERTY.  That means that to undo I have to press ⌘-/ (since in Dvorak, z is mapped to the / key).

What's worse is that the hotkey for redo (Shift-⌘-Z) doesn't work at all even if I use the / key.  I know it's weird to use a Dvorak keyboard but it's crippling not to be able to use hotkeys like a normal user.  It does work when I switch to the plain Dvorak layout (though that makes hotkeys awkward everywhere).

I'm set up to build Godot from source so if anybody could point me to the appropriate way to fix this problem, I could give it a shot?  Being able to remap hotkeys in the editor is probably the ideal solution but for now I'd settle for an under-the-hood fix.

data.title: 3D Collision Shape Crash
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 8
Lenovo Z580 ideapad

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Changing the the shape on a CollisionShape node causes Godot to crash.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a new project.
Add a root node.
Add a CollisionShape node.
Change the shape of the node.
Crash.

data.title: _input_event(event) is called after _input(event)
data.body:
Linux x64

According to the documentation the call order for input events is  _input_event(event) then _input(event) as described here:
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/engine/inputevent.html
But _input(event) is always called before _input_event(event)

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12592569/14685934/f77d510a-0736-11e6-8c21-fe7455c37996.png)

tested in 1.1 stable 2.0 stable 2.0.2 stable and compiled from source 19.4.2016 under Linux x64

minimal example 
[input_eve.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/228586/input_eve.zip)

data.title: Trim whitespace (on save) in script editor
data.body:
A very small feature request... more like a "nice to have" as some user action could easy workaround this problem, but it's nasty =)

It often happens that there are several useless tabs left over after working with the script editor.
For example, writing a function body, then pressing enter twice to insert a blank line and start writing a new function signature below it leaves some tabs directly above (as many as the last indent of the previous function was).
In the end, there are a lot of useless tabs above function signatures, different in numbers for each line.

Example:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9631152/14677687/e50a4b14-0712-11e6-99a4-986756e2b6f1.png)

If the editior would trim whitespace on save:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9631152/14677713/01800978-0713-11e6-9abb-506fecec5139.png)

data.title: Fix setting minimum size for autowrap labels in VBoxContainer and HBoxContainer
data.body:
When you set autowrap to label in VBoxContainer it disappear. This little patch fix it for my projects.
For HboxContainer you must set min width or/and set horizontal size flags to expand if you want it grow with HboxContainer.

data.title: Add a way to add categories to the script variables section from GDScript
data.body:
(Inspired by [a question on QA](http://godotengine.org/qa/3196/how-add-subcategories-inspector-script-variables-section))

When doing scripts with a lot of configurable variables, it is nice to be able to group them in the inspector. 

So, instead of having:

```
> Script Variables
| - Not totally unrelated var = false
| - Unrotate children = true
| - Rotate speed = 60
| - Rotate timeout = 100
| - ...
```

We can have

```
> Script Variables
| - Not totally unrelated var = false
| > Rotate
| | - Unrotate children = true
| | - Rotate speed = 60
| | - Rotate timeout = 100
| - ...
```

---

With @kubecz3k we discussed on IRC about how might we do the syntax, and we ended up with the following:
- (1) A new keyword that starts a category
  - Pros: Allows for this issue to be closed
  - Cons: Impossible to end a category, no nesting

``` gd
category rotate
export var unrotate_children = false
```
- (2) An addition to export hints
  - Pros: Not much additional code to be written
  - Cons: You have to retype the name of the category for each variable

``` gd
export("rotate") var unrotate_children = false
export("rotate", float) var rotate_speed = 60
```
- (3) Allow variables with non-identifier names
  - Pros: Stuff like CJK support comes naturally
  - Cons: You have to retype the name of the category for each variable, doesn't look good at all

``` gd
export var "rotate/unrotate_children" = false
```
- (4) Add a keyword that starts a "category block"
  - Pros: Which variable is where is evident from afar, nesting of categories is supported
  - Cons: Raises suspicion on how to get that variable... should it be via `category_name.variable_name`, or just `variable_name`

``` gd
category rotate:
    export var unrotate_children = false
```

@reduz ~ Which one of the four proposals above do you like the most?

data.title: Fix key events in web export
data.body:
Key events in web export should now fully work in all browsers (IE11 would work too, but can't get it to start...).

This change even provides `unicode` values in key release events (in browsers supporting `key` or `char`), which other OS don't do. Don't know if this is by intention or limitation.

Fixes #2761

Probably fixes _ #3862 as well, as explained there, but let's give it some time to see if we get a reply

data.title: Add JavaScript eval interface to web export
data.body:
This change allows calling JavaScript from GDScript in the browser per JS's `eval`. It's accessible as singleton `JavaScript` from `Globals`, using the function `eval( code, return_type )`.

The usual ritual may be necessary: http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/services_for_ios.html#multi-platform-games

EDIT:
Function signature has changed to `eval( String code, bool use_global_execution_context)`, return type is inferred

data.title: Fix default clear color in web export
data.body:
Change setting the default clear color so it doesn't depend on a boot logo.

Fixes #2766

data.title: Theme not finding an image makes FileSystem view stuck forever
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 Pro x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I created a Theme referencing a texture for use in a Button class. After renaming the texture, the FileSystem view gets stuck at "Scanning files" forever, and reopening the project doesn't help.
Additionally, in a bigger game project, I cannot close the editor anymore as it freezes upon attempting to do so, and I have to kill its process. (I could not reproduce that in the sample project linked below).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open the project I linked below. The FileSystem view is stuck at "Scanning Files".
The Button.png texture file was renamed to Button_renamed.png before.

**Link to minimal example project**:
[DickTheme.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/228076/DickTheme.zip)

data.title: Add preview of the Camera2D's screen boundaries
data.body:
Closes #3365

This implementation does not apply smoothing _nor drag margins_ to the preview, which might be misleading in some cases (e.g. you still have to make sure the player can see what is displayed). This is not much of an issue though, since most of the time you would either position the camera at a starting location, or you would animate a non-interpolating camera around.

data.title: GDscript Enhancement: Reflection
data.body:
What if I want to make a game which allows players to write their own code and then executes the code?
I found that I can create a GDScript and then use `get_method_list()`, but there is no more hint.
What I know is only this method returns an array.
I think it is good to have a function like `vars` in python or `Object.has_property`.
Also, add a function which can `execute` code embedded is better.
But be careful, a history told from python tells us it is very important to **isolate** the code in a new namespace.

data.title: Wrong word choice in doc
data.body:
see here:
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/gdscript.html#sub-classes
what? subclass?
maybe you should call them "Inner classes", but definitely not "Sub classses".

data.title: Documentation generator for gdscript
data.body:
Have a javadoc-like documentation generator system for gdscript, such that documentation can be written in the comments (aka, contracts). This could also be made to generate documentation towards godots built-in class reference, and it could also allow for static typing (by specifying the type in the contract). 

Example:

``` javascript
 # @method foo
 # @param bar extends Node
 # @return extends Reference
 func foo(bar):
     return bar
```

So what are your thoughts on this?

data.title: remove unused resources and add korean locale for android
data.body:
- remove unused resources in platform/android/java/res/values/strings.xml
- add korean language resource for apk expansion download screen

data.title: Incorrect mouse position in Node2Ds under CanvasLayer
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.0.2, Windows 7 64 bits.

In my game, I put the HUD inside a CanvasLayer, but mouse position returned by get_global_mouse_pos() is incorrect when nodes go deeper in hierarchy.
If node A is child of a CanvasLayer, reported position is fine, relative to the layer and not the level's camera.
However, if B is child of A, mouse position is incorrect and is reported as if B was a sibling of CanvasLayer, so the camera of the level ends up being used as reference.

Because of this, I can't create clickable custom controls because get_global_mouse_pos() doesn't works as expected.

Sample project: http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/GlobalMousePosLayer.zip
Start new_scene.tscn, then click the sprite on the top-left. Two positions are printed, one for node A, one for node B. Both should be equal, but B is incorrect.

Might be related (or maybe not): https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/2306

data.title: Add more small utility effects like modulate
data.body:
Hello,
On my game I developed some utility shaders because enemies flash white when they take damage or some sprites need inverted colors and I couldn't achieve those effects with modulate, this escalates so bad with multiple sprites because they need a shader with the UNIQUE flag for each one, this gets even worse if some enemies needs another shader behaviour.

For that reason I propose a change on modulate section from Sprite and Animated Sprite.
The idea is to support more lightweight utility effects of common use and let's the user cycle between them, only one effect is active at time for each sprite and could be cycled by animations or scripts included his properties.

Proposed changes to godot GUI to support this:
![Image NewGui](http://i.imgur.com/UJyWSWU.png)
- Move the Modulate to a new section called Effects
- Here you could select the current effect from a dropbox, default one is modulate with white
- Display controls related for each effect when one is selected

And here is video from a prototype of how this section could behave:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/xc06512cg9rdswm/2016-04-18_16-13-22.mp4?dl=0

Examples of posible new effects:
Additive Blending: make enemies flash white or another light recolor
Silhouette: change sprite to a solid color, could be used to make enemies flash white too
Desaturate: convert sprites to shades of grey
Inverse: invert colors of a sprite

So what do you think about this idea?

data.title: AnimationPlayer doesn't like spaces in animation name under tscn
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

Arch Linux

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I was fiddling with AnimationPlayer and realized that it didn't autoplay an animation that was called `New Anim` (the default name). Soon I tried to `play()` it directly from code, but that started spawning errors like:

```
play: Animation not found: New Anim
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create an AnimationPlayer node and create a new animation. Use the default name.
- Create a script on the AnimationPlayer and insert the following code:

```
extends AnimationPlayer

func _ready():
    get_node("AnimationPlayer").play("New Anim")
```
- Save scene as `.tscn` and play
- Observe that (1) the animation doesn't play, and (2) there is an error in the debugger
- Save scene as `.xscn` and play
- Observe that (1) the animation now plays, and (2) no errors are present.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Tooltips for variables retain value after ending Debug session
data.body:
When setting a breakpoint to see some variable values in tooltips that appear when you hover the mouse over them, they work as intended. But it is weird that they still show the same values after ending (stopping) debugging when hovering the mouse over them.

It is kind of misleading since I though I changed their values somewhere in script. Which I didn't.
It is a minor issue though, tooltips need to be reset to their original values after ending debug session.

This happens even on the latest dev build as of writing this.

data.title: 'missing' feature in ShaderGraph: boolean uniform.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
All supported?

**Issue description:**
Shader Language supports booleans but no boolean uniforms can be added in shaderGraph.
IMO, it would be nice if shaderGraph could do anything the shaderLang can & vice versa.
The main reason I request for this however is simply because it would allow me to create better shader/material UI's for the shaders I intend to share with the community:

![booluniforms](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3162126/14590678/5a11b638-0509-11e6-9b4b-4fa2baee529a.png)
NB: I have moved the Flip Bump V in the image for shaderGraph, but it was actually placed entirely randomly in between 'Metallicness' and 'Specular Exponent'.

While I can clamp the scalar uniform's values in shader to 0...1 range(min/max) - in the UI the user will still be able to input greater or negative values and that could lead to confusion. Using a boolean Uniform in place of the scalar uniforms would however make everything much clearer.

As a node the boolean uniform should take a name variable similar to other uniforms, and output either a 0 or a 1 depending on it's state. 0 for false, 1 for true. Or alternatively the values for false and true could be over-writable, i.e. be usable for any switches.

data.title: Project settings window; do not expose settings that likely lead to bugs or other issues.
data.body:
The reason I opened this issue is because I just found one setting that can be a potential troublemaker when it comes to being able to debug and monitor a project.
![godot_donottouch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10081256/14589644/e96a5374-04ac-11e6-8f44-b51d6101cd25.png)

The setting highlighted in the image is exposed to the user for whatever reason, but if you set it to a different value, you can potentially cause the debugger and info windows to stop working after saving the project and closing/reopening (changing it back likewise makes everything work again). Good thing too since working on my project was slow without error reporting and prints.

My suggestion is that the developers work to remove the exposure of various technical functions that are likely to cause bugs and development trouble if they are changed at all. For instance, I would at least keep the _message queue-size_ parameter in the **core** category because an increase in that value is needed if you are to have large scenes, but there's others that appear to be so technical that only a C++ coder might actually know what they are and what they do (and if a user who only knows GDscript messes with them, who knows what issues will crop up).

Thoughts?
